title: N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. Tit. 14 §§ 635-6.6 - Moveable equipment and personal property
content:
N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. Tit. 14 §§ 635-6.6 - Moveable equipment and personal property

State Regulations
(a) Costs of ownership of moveable equipment
and personal property shall be allowable in the amount of depreciation and
interest if the purchase is made through a multiple bid process. Depreciation
shall be based upon the historical cost and useful life. (1)

If the equipment or personal property is
purchased from a party not related to the provider or individual, the
historical cost shall be the lesser of the actual cost of purchasing the
equipment or personal property or the fair market value of such equipment or
personal property. (2)

If the
equipment or personal property is purchased from a party related to the
provider or the individual, the historical cost shall be the least of: (i) actual acquisition cost; (ii)
fair market value; or
(iii)
the seller's cost. (3)

The useful life is the higher of the
reported useful life or the useful life as reported in the Estimated Useful

Lives of Depreciable Hospital Assets, (2004 edition), published by Health

Forum, Inc., an American Hospital Association company, One North Franklin, 28th

Floor, Chicago, IL 60606-3421. A provider or individual may use a different
useful life if such different useful life is approved by OPWDD. OPWDD shall
base such approval upon historical experience and documentary
evidence. (4)

The provider or
individual shall use the straight-line, double declining balance or
sum-of-the-years' digits depreciation method. Once selected, the depreciation
method shall remain constant for the useful life of the asset. (b) Costs of leasing moveable
equipment and personal property shall be allowable as follows: (1)

If lease payments are made to a party
which is not a related party, allowable costs shall be the lesser of: (i) actual lease payments; or
(ii)
fair market rental. (2)

If lease payments are made to a related
party, allowable costs shall be the least of: (i) actual lease payments; (ii)
fair market rental; or
(iii)
allowable depreciation, the associated
interest expense, if any, and other related expenses, including, but not
limited to, maintenance costs. Notes
